title: What separates an amazing comedian from an average one? - Quora

response.answer_text: This reminds me of when I was working door at a club. A guy comes in as the band is playing. I tell him that the cover is 10 bucks. He asks if he can stand there for a second to see if he likes the band. After a song he starts peppering me with questions like, “What is it that a band has that will take them to stardom?” It turns out that he was the guitarist/manager for his own band and was looking for an angle… as if this kind of alchemy can be distilled. I’ve seen thousands of bands in my time. I saw Nickelback play to 18 people in a club on their first tour of Canada. I have no answer for why some bands become mega-stars and others don’t.They tried to make Paris Hilton a music star. They tried with Lindsay Lohan. Then the “Cash me Outside” girl from Dr. Phil gets signed and sells a million records. Movie stars… for every guy like “The Rock” or “Jason Statham” there’s a “Howie Long” or “Rowdie Roddy Piper” (I STILL love, “They Live” BTW). And who can explain “Ahnold”? Dude could barely speak English! If they knew what it took to be a star, no movie would ever bomb and every record would be platinum. To quote the late William Goldman, “No one knows anything.” I think it’s the same with comedy. What separates a great comedian from an average one? They have that, “something-something” that takes them to the next level. Full disclosure, I NEVER thought that Roseanne Barr’s standup was funny. I refused to watch her show because her voice annoyed the hell out of me. Mega-star. I saw Sam Kinison do a club show. Half the audience walked out on him (including me and my girlfriend). 2 years later he’s the biggest comic in Hollywood. Russel Peters can NOT break through into movies despite selling out stadiums. Then you get a comic’s comic… a guy like Norm MacDonald (from my home town, BTW. I saw him when he was first starting out). Norm is loved by all comics. They call him a genius. Norm is not a star. Norm would be lucky to sell more than 500 tickets to a comedy show. So, not even a comic knows what separates the greats from the goods.

My friends are comedians. Really funny and amazing people. All at various stages of their career. Here’s us at one of our house parties.  In this pic (or often at the parties) are all types of comedians: Dane Cook, Seth Green, Matt Rife, Kevin Miles, Vinny Fasline, David Sullivan, Rick Glassman, King Bach, Daniel Van Kirk and several others. They’re all at different stages of their careers. Everything is a spectrum. Multiple instances must come together is a person’s lifetime to help them achieve stardom, success and separate them from average comedians. A few things you can control: Practice like there’s no going back. This is common amongst all the greats.Live in a city that fosters comedians. In America, that’s likely Los Angeles, NYC or Chicago.God given talent. (It’s a euphemism don’t hate). Some people are born funny (not me). This is a tremendous advantage, but still requires the other points. Ok, you can’t really control this so much but it is still critical to know your strengths and weaknesses.Find friends that help and foster your creativity, comedy and career. It’s a long road filled with ups-and-downs. You’ll need people who genuinely want to help you and see you succeed. Fans come and go, friends are there when you need them.Obsessed with perfecting their craft. Almost every waking moment find inspiration, study past comedians, record and watch your performances, understand the cadence of your own voice, practice your mannerisms, practice timing, practice writing, practice improv, practice with an audience, practice skits, practice and watch every nuance of your performance.Don’t let the haters get to you, but take constructive criticism from people you respect and trust.My friends are hilarious. They’re also great humans.
